You are releasing your film backwards on YouTube and the best practice would be to release it backwards. What the H-E double hockey sticks(HELL) does that mean? ❗ The current model goes something like this… -Release teaser trailer -Release behind the scenes/making of movie -Release snippets or scenes from the movie -Release full trailer -Release film That feels backwards! So do that backwards for a better model. Why does that feel backwards? Because you are emulating an old model to build as much awareness and exposure as possible to get an audience to pay and see your film in one large short burst - the release weekend in cinemas. But that's not how YouTube works. YouTube is a platform of instant gratification, so give the users what they want right away. So here is what I would do instead. -Release film Now that you have the film released, you have a way to point all the attention from the rest of the stuff below, to your film. -Release teaser trailer -Release behind the scenes/making of -Release snippets and scenes from the film -Release the official trailer At the end of each of those videos, you can go ahead and direct the viewer to watch the official film. On YouTube it doesn't matter if the film is there first. That's not the game, the game is long tail. Meaning you are driving consistent and constant attention to the film that is already released...not the film you are about to release. Now this isn't to say you can't or shouldn't have some sort of promo material before hand, but don't put all the promo and marketing upfront, save a majority of it after you post the film. Your goal isn't to build awareness BEFORE the film, it is to drive audience engagement AFTER ther film is released. Then you will drive a whole lot more traffic to your film.

This article is absolutely bonkers. A movie director named Carl Rinsch sells a show to Netflix for around $61 million dollars. Rinsch’s most famous movie is 47 Ronin starring Keanu Reeves. The director spends $44 million on the series then says he needs another $11 million. So far so good…but he takes the $11 million and deposits it into a brokerage account and loses about $5.9 million trading stocks. Then takes what’s left and buys DOGE coin the crypto with the cute Shiba Inu logo. The $4 million becomes $27 million. Thomas Cherian, a spokesperson for Netflix, told The Times that they've written off Rinsch's series, adding that it was "clear that Mr. Rinsch was never going to complete the project he agreed to make." Rinsch declined to answer The Times' questions when contacted for comment. Rinsch and Netflix are currently undergoing confidential arbitration proceedings, per The Times. Rinsch, who The Times said had initiated the arbitration, says Netflix owes him at least $14 million in damages for breaching their contract. How did this happen? Did any of the money get spent on the series? I’d like to see a documentary on this whole situation. https://lnkd.in/gAGvnqpk
